translated: 13 Commentary on the Verses of the Abhidharma-koÅ›a, Treatise, Section 15
From here, the fifth major section. Clarifying the differences in obtaining the three disciplines. Within this, first clarifying
the similarities and differences in obtaining the time and place. Second, clarifying the sentient beings, factors, and causes. Third, clarifying the obtaining of the evil place
within.
Below this, the first clarifies the similarities and differences in obtaining the time and place.
The treatise states:
This is the liberation of the precepts.
The meditation and impurity.
The three kinds of disciplines.
From obtaining this, one obtains one.
Can one also obtain the other two?
If not, how is it?
The verse says:
From all, the two present, one obtains the discipline of the desire realm.
From the fundamental, always, one obtains the meditation and impurity.
The commentary says:
The two lines above.
Clarify the obtaining of the precepts of liberation.
The two lines below.
Clarify the obtaining of the precepts of concentration and the path.
From all, the two present, one obtains the discipline of the desire realm means:
First, from all,
one obtains the discipline of desire.
Second, from the two, one obtains the discipline of the desire realm.
Third, from the present, one obtains the discipline of desire.
From all means:
The fundamental karmic paths.
The preparatory and subsequent actions.
This place where offenses are committed,
Is called all.
That is, the prÄtimoká¹£a.
Because it is free from the offenses of the fundamental transgressions and the preparatory and subsequent offenses.
In all places where evil is committed,
One attains the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts.
Obtained from two means:
The two refer to two categories.
First, the category of sentient beings.
Natural offenses and prohibited offenses.
Natural means killing and so forth.
Prohibited means sleeping in the same room with a woman and so forth.
Second, the category of insentient beings.
Natural offenses and prohibited offenses.
Natural means stealing external property.
Prohibited means digging the earth and so forth.
Now, in receiving the wholesome precepts,
One is able to avoid natural offenses and prohibited offenses.
Therefore, from the places where offenses are committed in the two categories,
One attains the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts.
Obtained from the present means:
The treatise says:
It means obtaining it from the aggregates, sense bases, and elements of the present world.
Not from the past or future.
It means that this discipline,
It arises in the realm of sentient beings.
Because past and future are not the realm of sentient beings. The commentary explains:
The realm of sentient beings.
One sentient being.
Two realms of sentient beings.
The realm has two kinds.
One is the realm of the basis.
Two is the realm of the place where one abides.
By abstaining from sexual misconduct,
one generates precepts on the side of guarding sentient beings.
If one abstains from killing,
one generates precepts in the realm of the basis of sentient beings.
If one does not dig the ground,ğŸ”½one generates precepts in the realm of the place where sentient beings abide.
As for one obtains the dhyÄna and pure precepts from the root and constantly,
one obtains the dhyÄna and pure precepts from the root.
Two obtains the dhyÄna and pure precepts constantly.
As for from the root,
it means one obtains the precepts of concentration and the path from the place of the fundamental karmic path.
These two precepts,
within the state of concentration,
only have the fundamental.
Before and after concentration,
there are no such precepts.
Therefore, there is no preparatory or subsequent stage.
Because the precepts of concentration and the path only exist in the fundamental stage.
Therefore, when one obtains the precepts,
One obtains them only in relation to the evil realms that are the fundamental stage.
The precepts of individual liberation.
The preparatory and subsequent stages.
Are all possible.
Therefore, in the three stages,
One gives rise to and obtains the precepts.
The treatise says:
If one obtains the regulation of concentration and the undefiled precepts,
One should know that they only arise from the fundamental karmic paths.
One does not even obtain them from their preparatory and subsequent stages,
Let alone from the prohibited offenses. The treatise above is finished. The second, obtaining from the constant time, means the three times.
It means that one gives rise to the precepts of concentration and the path from the three times.
Because the precepts of concentration and the path
Co-arise with the mind.
It means that the mind that co-arises with the precepts can contemplate the three times.
Therefore, the precepts that co-arise with the mind also prevent the three times.
Due to the above distinctions,
One should make four statements. The treatise says: The first statement is:
That is, from the present preparatory and subsequent actions and the various offenses that are prohibited, because they are in the present,
one obtains the precepts of individual liberation.
Because of the preparatory actions, etc.,
one does not obtain the precepts of concentration and the path. The second case is
that from the past and future fundamental paths of action, because they are fundamental,
one obtains the precepts of concentration and the path.
Because they are past and future,
one does not obtain the precepts of individual liberation. The third case is that from the present fundamental paths of action, because they are present,
one obtains the precepts of individual liberation.
Because they are fundamental,
one obtains the precepts of concentration and the path. The fourth case is
that from the past and future preparatory and subsequent actions, because they are past and future,
there are no precepts of individual liberation.
Because they are preparatory actions, etc.,
there are no precepts of concentration and the path. The treatise also says:
When one obtains the precepts of good conduct,
one definitely does not have present evil paths of action, etc.
Therefore, one should say that one obtains them from the present realm.
In reality, one should say that one guards against the future.
It is definitely not appropriate to say that it guards against past and present offenses.
This passage is the treatise author's
criticism of the third interpretation above.
The first sentence
refers to the correct attainment of wholesome precepts.
How could there be
evil karmic paths, etc. in the present?
The first sentence is extended to include
the preparatory and subsequent actions, as well as the proscribed offenses.
The criticism is that the word already should be used.
Therefore, it should be said that one obtains it from the present basis.
This means that
the first and third sentences
should add the word basis.
The meaning is then unobstructed.
It means that although there is no substance of karmic paths, etc. in the present,
there is a basis for giving rise to karma, etc.
Therefore, with regard to the basis of karmic paths, etc.,ğŸ”½the meaning of giving rise to precepts is unobstructed.
If discussing the giving rise to precepts,
there is a commonality with the three time periods.
As for preventing offenses, it should be the future,
because it prevents them from arising.
The past has already ceased,
and the present has already arisen.
It cannot be prevented.
From here is the second part.
As for the causes and conditions of sentient beings,
the treatise states:
Those who have obtained the precepts and non-precepts,
from all sentient beings, causes and conditions,
are there differences or not?
This definitely has differences.
What are the differences?
The verse says:
The precepts are from all sentient beings, the causes and conditions are said to be indefinite.
Non-precepts are from all sentient beings, the causes are not from the conditions.
The commentary says:ğŸ”½As for the precepts being from all sentient beings,
they are from all sentient beings.
Because the precepts are generated.
Because the precepts are generated only when abiding in a wholesome attitude towards all sentient beings.
If it were different, it would not be so.
Because an evil attitude is not completely extinguished.
As for the causes and conditions being said to be indefinite,
the causes refer to the seven causes.
The conditions refer to the mind of receiving the precepts. As for the causes being indefinite,ğŸ”½some obtain them from all causes, referring to the precepts of a fully ordained monk.
Some obtain them from four causes, referring to the precepts of a novice monk and so forth.
As for the conditions being indefinite,
Or there may be one who abides in the precepts but not for all causes.
This refers to one who may have a lower mind,
or a middling or superior mind.
Receiving the precepts of the upavÄsa, upavÄsastha, and Å›rÄmaá¹‡era.
Or there may be one who abides in the precepts due to all causes.
This refers to one who, with a lower mind, receives the upavÄsastha precepts, and then arouses a middling mind,
receiving the Å›rÄmaá¹‡era precepts.
Later, arousing a superior mind,
receiving the bhiká¹£u precepts.
Endowed with these three minds,
it is called all causes.
The treatise says:
If a person does not make five kinds of fixed limits,
then they can receive the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts.
This refers to the fixed limits of sentient beings, branches, place, time, and conditions. The fixed limit of sentient beings means
thinking, I will only refrain from killing and so forth towards a certain type of sentient being.
As for the fixed limit of branches,
thinking, I can only uphold and not violate a certain branch of the precepts.
As for the fixed limit of place,
thinking, I will only refrain from killing and so forth in a certain region.
As for the fixed limit of time,
I only remember on such-and-such a day, month, etc.
Thinking, I will only be able to abstain from killing and so forth on such and such a day, month, and so forth.
Saying, Conditions,
thinking, I will only be able to abstain from killing and so forth except in the case of battle and so forth.
If one undertakes the precepts with these five kinds of fixed limits,
one does not obtain the precepts,
but only precepts-like good conduct.
As for the non-restraints, they are obtained from all sentient beings, from all parts, and not from all causes.
This refers to non-restraints.
They are obtained from all sentient beings.
Because the mind intends to kill all sentient beings.
They are obtained from all parts.
This refers to non-restraints.
They are fully endowed with all parts.
The three bodily and four verbal [actions].
Because all are committed as evil.ğŸ”½As for not from all causes,
not from all causes.
Because the inferior and other minds
do not arise together.
Question: As for butchers of sheep and so forth,
people with non-restraints,
in one lifetime,
do not take what is not given,
with regard to their own wives and concubines,
they abide with a mind of contentment,
and are mute and unable to speak,
There are four faults in not speaking.
How can one possess all the branches there?
Answer: Because it completely damages the intention of good. Intention means intention. Although mute and not speaking,
One uses one's fingers to direct and express the meaning one wants to say with one's body.
Therefore, one can possess the branches.
If one does not vow to the end of one's life,
And does not possess the branches,
And does not extend to all sentient beings,
One only obtains the evil of the middle ground,
And is not called one of undisciplined conduct. According to the SautrÄntika school,
According to the duration of the vow,
Whether the branches are complete or not,
Regarding all sentient beings,
Whether one extends to them or not,
One still obtains undisciplined conduct.
The precepts of the lay practitioner are also like this.
According to how much one takes on,
One all obtains the precepts.
Only the eight precepts are excluded.
Because the time is short,
One must possess the branches
And extend to all sentient beings,
Only then can one give rise to the precepts.
As for those of undisciplined conduct,

Namely, butchers of sheep, chickens, pigs, birds, fish, beasts, robbers, executioners, jailers, snake charmers, dog cookers, hunters, evil kings, those who administer punishments, those who listen and investigate, and those who pass judgment.
As for snake charmers,
it means using spells
to bind dragons and snakes.
Seeking things for entertainment,
they make a living for themselves.
As for dog cookers,
it refers to evil Chandalas in the Western Regions.
They are called dog cookers.
Perhaps they cook dogs to fill their stomachs.
As for those who listen and investigate,
it refers to censors and others.
As for those who pass judgment,
it refers to the Ministry of Justice and others.
From here is the third part.
It clarifies obtaining the evil state.
The treatise states:
It has been explained how one obtains non-discipline.
One obtains non-discipline and other non-manifestations.
How is it done?
The other non-manifestations that have not been explained will be explained.
It refers to the neutral state.
The verse says:ğŸ”½One obtains non-discipline
by action and by vowing to receive it.ğŸ”½One obtains the other non-manifest karma
by field, by receiving, and by heavy practice.
The commentary says:
The first two lines
are the means of obtaining evil precepts.
The last two lines
are the means of obtaining neutral [precepts].
One obtains non-discipline
by two causes:
First, by action;
second, by vowing to receive it.
By action means
that one is born in a family of non-discipline.
First, one kills and so forth,
and when one initiates the practice,
one then gives rise to evil precepts.
That is, one is born in a butcher's family.
From a young age, one sees killing
and gives rise to a light vowing mind,
not giving rise to evil precepts.
One must kill and so forth
to obtain non-discipline.
Second, by vowing means
that one is born in another family.
For the sake of making a living,
one harbors thoughts of killing and harming,
and then makes a vow, saying:
From this day forth,
until the end of my life,
It means thinking, I will do such and such work to support myself.
When one gives rise to this vow,
one then gives rise to unwholesome precepts.
It means being born in other families.
From a young age,
one has never seen killing.
The vow must be heavy.
Therefore, one gives rise to unwholesome precepts.
As for obtaining the other non-manifestations,
the other refers to the non-manifestations of the other neutral [actions].ğŸ”½Due to the field and the weight of the practice,
one obtains the cause of the neutral [actions].
First,
due to the field.ğŸ”½It refers to giving a garden or forest, etc.
to such and such fields of blessings.
The non-manifestations of that giving
arise upon the initial giving.
Second,
due to the vow.
It refers to making a vow, saying,
If I have not yet paid homage to the Buddha,
I will not eat first, etc.
On the day of the fast,
one vows to always give food.
Simply giving rise to the vow,
one immediately gives rise to the non-manifestations.
Third,
due to the action.
It refers to giving rise to such an earnest thought,
practicing good or evil.
then the unmanifest [karma] arises.
By means of these three causes,
one obtains the other unmanifest [karma].
This is the fourth major section below.
It clarifies the distinctions in relinquishment.ğŸ”½Within this, the first is the relinquishment of the prÄtimoká¹£a discipline.
The second is the relinquishment of the discipline of concentration and the path.
The third is the relinquishment of the unwholesome restraints.
The fourth is the relinquishment of the neutral [restraints].
The fifth is the relinquishment of the various non-form [dharmas].
This is the first below.
It clarifies the relinquishment of the prÄtimoká¹£a discipline.
The treatise states:
Thus, the obtaining of the disciplines, etc.
The relinquishment of the disciplines, etc.
has not yet been explained, but will be explained.
First, what is it?
The relinquishment of the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts.
The verse says:
The prÄtimoká¹£a discipline is relinquished by intention, death,
The arising of both sexes, severing the wholesome roots, the end of the night,
Some say it is by committing a grave offense, others say by the disappearance of the Dharma.
The KÄÅ›mÄ«rans say it is by committing two [offenses], like incurring a debt.
The commentary says:
The first four lines
are the established view.
The fifth line
is the SautrÄntika view.
The sixth sentence.
The Dharma-secret school.
The last two sentences.
There are difficulties in understanding the scriptures.
As for the word taming,
It is meant to illustrate the precepts.
Because this can cause the faculties to be tamed.
Excluding the precepts of the near-dwelling.
The remaining precepts.
Are abandoned due to four conditions.
First, by intentional abandonment.
Three conditions must be met.
First, by the intention of being disgusted with the precepts.
Second, by understanding the other person and acknowledging it.
Third, by uttering the words of abandonment, which violates the expression of acceptance.
If the three conditions are incomplete,ğŸ”½Abandoning the precepts is not accomplished.
It is not only by giving rise to the mind.
That is to say, in a dream,ğŸ”½Abandonment is not accomplished.
It is not only by giving rise to expression.
The deluded mind and so forth.
Do not constitute abandonment.
It is not only these two.
Facing animals and so forth.
Abandonment is not accomplished.
Therefore, these three are complete.
Only then is it considered abandonment.
Second, by the end of life.
The precepts are obtained based on the body.
When the basis is abandoned,
the precepts are abandoned accordingly. Third, by the simultaneous arising of the two sexes.
This refers to the arising of the male and female faculties.
Due to the transformation of the basis,
the mind also transforms accordingly.
Moreover, a person with two sexes
is not a basis for precepts.
Fourth, by severing the roots of goodness.
The precepts are generated by the mind.
When the wholesome mind is severed,
the precepts are also abandoned accordingly.
Fifth, by the end of the night.
Because the time limit for the precepts has passed.
The abandonment of the precepts of the near-attainers is due to the above five conditions.
The remaining disciplines
are only abandoned by four conditions.
That is, by excluding the end of the night.
Generally speaking, the prÄtimoká¹£a
is abandoned by five conditions. Some say it is by committing a grave offense.
The SautrÄntika school
says that if one commits any one of the four grave precepts,
one also abandons the precepts of the Å›rÄmaá¹‡era and bhiká¹£u.
Others say it is by the disappearance of the Dharma.
The Dharmaguptaka school
says that when the true Dharma disappears,
one abandons the prÄtimoká¹£a.
Because when the Dharma perishes, all precepts and boundary-making rituals cease.
The second is like a debtor with property.
The SarvÄstivÄda school.
Explains that committing a grave offense does not abandon the precepts.
The reason for this is:
Because if one violates one precept, all precepts should be abandoned.
Just as violating a partial defeat, etc.
Also does not abandon the precepts.
However, there are two names.
Namely, precepts and precepts that are violated.
As if one has property.
When one owes another a debt, one is called a wealthy person and one who owes a debt.
Violating the precepts is also like this.
If one confesses and repents of the offense,
One is called one who possesses moral discipline.
One is not called one who violates the precepts.
It is like one who repays a debt being called only a wealthy person.
Now I briefly describe the two schools.
The reason why the SautrÄntika school says that committing a grave offense abandons the precepts is:
Because the World-Honored One said, One who commits a grave offense is not a son of ÅšÄkya.
It harms the nature of a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
It destroys the body of a bhiká¹£u.
means to be destroyed and fall, and to be called by the name of the victor of others, PÄrÄyika.
This means the victor of others.
Evil dharmas are called others.
Others come and surpass oneself.
Since the World-Honored One has said that they are not the sons of ÅšÄkya, etc.,
it is clear that they have abandoned the precepts.
There is a comprehensive explanation.ğŸ”½The meaning of not a bhiká¹£u in this sÅ«tra
refers to not being a bhiká¹£u in the ultimate sense.
A bhiká¹£u in the ultimate sense is a noble person.
Because of committing a grave offense,
one does not attain the fruit of sagehood,
therefore it is said not a bhiká¹£u.
Moreover, the SautrÄntika school cites the Vinaya to clarify the four kinds of bhiká¹£us.
The first is called a similar bhiká¹£u, referring to a layperson who falsely claims to be a bhiká¹£u.
The second is called a self-proclaimed bhiká¹£u, referring to one who has committed a grave offense and calls oneself a bhiká¹£u.
The third is called a begging bhiká¹£u, referring to a renunciant.
One makes a living by begging.
The fourth is called a bhiká¹£u who has destroyed delusions, referring to a sage.
Since the Vinaya text says that one who has committed a grave offense
is not a bhiká¹£u,
it is called a self-proclaimed bhiká¹£u.
Therefore, it is known that the precepts are abandoned.
There is also a school that cites a sutra.
To prove that the precepts are not abandoned.
As the World-Honored One said.
Cunda, you should know.
There are four kinds of ascetics.
There is no fifth.
The four are called:
The first is the supreme path ascetic, referring to the Buddha and pratyekabuddhas.
Because they awaken by themselves.
The second is the path-showing ascetic, referring to ÅšÄriputra.
Because he expounds the Dharma and shows the path.
The third is the life-path ascetic, referring to Ä€nanda, because morality, concentration, and wisdom are his life.
The fourth is the defiled path ascetic, referring to a bhiká¹£u who has committed a grave offense.
The Vinaya says that a mahÄro refers to an old bhiká¹£u who likes to steal others' things.
This sutra says that one who has committed a grave offense is called a defiled path ascetic.
It is still called a bhiká¹£u.
It is clear that there are precepts. The SautrÄntika school explains:
It is called a bhiká¹£u because it resembles a bhiká¹£u.
It is not because it has the essence of precepts that it is called a bhiká¹£u.
The main point of the discussion is that
the SautrÄntika school is correct.
Therefore, the author of the treatise refutes the proponents of existence.
If such a person
still has the nature of a bhiká¹£u,
one should pay homage and respect to such a type of bhiká¹£u.
The author of the previous treatise on the Dharma-secret refutes this, saying:
When the true Dharma is about to perish,
although there are no more boundary-setting rituals or Vinaya,
one who has not yet attained the precepts
has no new attainment.
But for one who has already attained them,
there is also no meaning of relinquishment.
From here, the second [part]
clarifies the relinquishment of the precepts of meditative concentration and the path.
The treatise states:
The two types of precepts born from meditative concentration and the undefiled [precepts],
how are they to be relinquished?
The verse says:
The wholesome dharmas born from meditative concentration are relinquished by changing stages, regression, and so forth.
The holy [precepts] are relinquished by attaining fruition, perfecting the faculties, and regressing.
The commentary says:
The wholesome dharmas born from meditative concentration
are the topic.
By changing stages, regression, and so forth
clarifies the two conditions for relinquishment.ğŸ”½First, relinquishment by changing stages
refers to moving from a lower stage
When one is born in a higher stage,
one abandons the dharmas of the lower stage.
Or when one dies in a higher stage,
and is born in a lower stage,
one abandons the dharmas of the higher stage.
Second, by the attainment of regression.
That is, when one regresses and loses the superior samÄdhi,
the verse says and so on.
And so on includes the abandonment of the common lot of the assembly,
and also the abandonment of a portion of the superior wholesome roots.
The portion of the superior wholesome roots
refers only to the four of heat and so on.
These are called the superior wholesome roots.
If an ordinary person abandons them,ğŸ”½they are abandoned at the time of death.
Whether born in the same stage or a higher stage,
one abandons heat and so on.
Since they are abandoned in the same stage,
they are not abandoned by changing stages.
Because abandonment by changing stages is only from higher to lower.
This clarifies the abandonment of the precepts of concentration.
By the above three conditions,ğŸ”½just as the concentrations of the form realm are abandoned by changing stages and regression,
the formless concentrations are also abandoned in this way.
However, there is no moral discipline.
This differs from the form realm.
Abandoning the holy by attaining fruition, training in faculties, and losing through regression.
This clarifies the three conditions for abandoning the holy.
First, by attaining fruition.
If one attains the subsequent fruition,
one abandons the previous fruition path.
And the path of progress.
Second, by training in faculties.
That is, when one changes faculties, one abandons the path of dull faculties.
Third, by losing through regression.
One loses the fruition path and the path of superior fruition.
The path of progress is called the path of superior fruition.
Because it leads to superior fruition.
This text generally clarifies the abandonment of pure dharmas.
Because precepts follow the Dharma.
Therefore, one abandons pure precepts.
Also, it is the same as the above three conditions.
From here, third,
abandoning non-discipline.
The treatise states:
Thus, the abandonment of all disciplines has been explained.
Non-discipline.
How is it abandoned?
The verse says:
Abandoning evil precepts is due to death, attaining precepts, or the arising of two sexual organs.
The commentary says:
Abandoning non-discipline.
There are three conditions.
First, by death, because the basis is abandoned.
Second, by obtaining precepts.
That is, by obtaining the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts.
Or by obtaining the meditative discipline.
Evil precepts are then abandoned.
Third, by the birth of a hermaphrodite.
Because the basis changes.
The treatise says:
One who abides in evil precepts,
Although sometimes giving rise to the thought of non-action,
And putting down swords and other weapons,
If one does not obtain the various wholesome precepts,
The various evil precepts,
Cannot be abandoned.
It is like avoiding the causes of illness,
But not taking good medicine.
The illness is difficult to cure.
From here, fourth,
Abandoning the indeterminate in the middle.
The treatise says:
The indeterminate in the middle,
How is it abandoned?
The verse says:ğŸ”½Abandoning the middle by the power of receiving,
The end of activities and life roots.
The commentary says:
The indeterminate in the middle,
Is abandoned by six conditions.
The word by in the upper line and the word end in the lower line.
Speaking of the six perfections,
First, by the severing of the acceptance.
That is, abandoning what has been accepted.
Thinking like this:ğŸ”½From now on,
I abandon what was previously accepted.
Second, by the severing of power.
That is, the power of pure faith and afflictions.
The unmanifest action that is drawn by
The two limits of power.
When they are severed and destroyed,
The unmanifest action is then abandoned.
Third, by the severing of the action.
That is, not doing again as accepted.
Like previously paying homage to the Buddha, not doing it now.
Fourth, by the destruction of the object.
That is, the temple, bedding,
stÅ«pa, garden, forest,
and the things that are given,
are destroyed.
The unmanifest action is then abandoned.
Fifth, by the severing of life.
When life is severed and destroyed,
The unmanifest action is then abandoned.
Sixth, by the severing of the faculties.ğŸ”½The faculties refer to the roots of goodness.
Originally, because of the roots of goodness,
The unmanifest action in the middle is produced.
Now, when one gives rise to the practice
And severs the roots of goodness,
then one abandons the non-manifest action attracted by the roots of good.
The word roots in the verse.
In principle, it should apply to the roots of non-good.
That is to say, when one gives rise to the preparatory action.
And severs the roots of non-good.
One then abandons the neutral non-manifest action attracted by the roots of non-good.
The treatise text only says one who severs the roots of good.
It implicitly includes the roots of non-good. The word preparatory action means.
Because the neutral [roots] are inferior.
One only abandons them at the time of the preparatory action.
From here, the fifth.
Abandoning non-formative good and defiled [dharmas].
The treatise says:
The non-formative good of the desire [realm]
And all other non-formative defiled dharmas of the non-form [realm].
How are they abandoned?
The verse says:

It is called attaining the karma of separation from that realm.
This karma of separation, when the sage has not yet separated from the defilements,
Creates good and evil karma in this realm.
And the good karma cultivated in the state of separation from the defilements.
This kind of karma,
The karma that is definite in ripening but indefinite in time,
This karma is definitely able to attract the fruit of the present life.
That is to say, in this realm,
One does not receive birth again.
Therefore it attracts the fruit of the present life.
If in this realm,
There is definite karma for birth later,
They definitely do not have the meaning of permanently separating from defilements, but must be reborn later.
They definitely do not have the meaning of permanently separating from defilements, and they will definitely experience the ripening of their karma in a later life.
If the ripening and the time are both indeterminate,
because of permanently separating from defilements,
one will not experience the ripening again.

The treatise states:
Is there only retribution of mental feeling,
or retribution of bodily feeling but not mental feeling?
There is also. How so?
The verse says:
It is allowed that the karma of good without initial thought only produces mental feeling.
Evil only produces bodily feeling. This is the difference in the karma of feeling.
The commentary says:
The karma of good without initial thought refers to
from the intermediate concentration and above,

This is called karma without initial thought.
It only produces mental feeling.

From here, the second.
Clarifying the madness of the mind, etc.
The treatise says:
Sentient beings' minds are mad.
What consciousness and realm is it based on?
The verse says:
Mad mind is only mental consciousness, born from karmic ripening.
And fear, harm, and sorrow, except in the northern continent, in the desire realm.
The commentary says:
The mad mind is only mental consciousness.
Because the five consciousness groups are non-discriminating,
There is definitely no mad mind.
Therefore, the mad mind.
Is only in mental consciousness.
Born from karmic ripening means:
The following clarifies that madness has five causes in total.
First, born from karmic ripening.
Refers to using drugs and spells.
To make others' minds go mad.
Or to make others drink poisonous drugs or alcohol.
Or to display awesome dignity.
Frightening birds and beasts,
Or setting fires to burn mountains,
Or creating pits and traps,
Harming sentient beings,
Or other activities that cause others to lose their mindfulness.
Because of this, in the future one will experience a specific ripening,
Causing the mind to become deranged.
And by fear, harm, obstruction, and sorrow.
Second, by fear.
Non-humans are frightened and thus cause the mind to become deranged.
Third, by harm.
It means to harass non-humans.
Because non-humans are angry,
They injure the limbs and joints,
Causing the mind to become deranged.
Fourth, by obstruction.
The great elements are obstructed,
Causing the mind to become deranged.
Fifth, by sorrow.
It means to lose one's parents and loved ones,
Sorrowing and worrying to the point of insanity.
Like Vasiá¹£á¹­ha and others.
Excluding the northern continent, in the desire realm.
It clarifies the location.
In the desire realm, in the five destinies,
All may have insanity.
In hell, one is always insane.
In other destinies, it may occur.
Among the sages in the desire realm,
The Buddha has no insanity.
The other sages,
the great elements are in conflict,
may have a deranged mind, but there is no arising from karmic retribution.
Because they have attained sagehood,
there is also no fear or terror.
Because they have transcended the five fears, the fear of not making a living,
the fear of a bad reputation,
the fear of the great assembly,
the fear of death,
and the fear of the evil realms.
There is also no harm or injury,
because non-humans respect them.
There is also no sorrow or worry,
because they have realized the nature of dharmas.
From here, the sixth,
clarifies crookedness, impurity, and turbidity.
The treatise states:
It is said in the sutra that there are three kinds of karma,
namely crooked, impure, and turbid.
What are their characteristics?
The verse says:
It is said that crooked, impure, and turbid karma arises from flattery, hatred, and greed.
The commentary says:
It is said means it is said in the sutra.ğŸ”½The three kinds of karma that arise from flattery are called crooked.
The three kinds of karma that arise from hatred are called impure.
